item.title: CS540-13 Minimax Algorithm
item.description:
Minimax Algorithm

function Max-Value(s)
inputs:
    s:current state in game, Max about to play
output: best-score (for Max) available from s
    if (s is a terminal state)
    then return (terminal value of s)
    else
        a = -INF
        for each s' in Succ(s)
            a = max(a, Min-Value(s'))
    return a

function Min-Value(s)
output: best-score(for Min) available from s
    if (s is a terminal state)
    then return (terminal value of s)
    else
        b = INF
        for each s' in Succ(s)
            b = min(b, Max-Value(s'))
    return b

Alpha-beta Motivation

  • Alpha pruning
  • Beta pruning

item.title: CS354-08 The Heap
item.description:
The heap

What? The heap is

  • a segment of a process’s variables used for dynamically allocated memory
  • a collection of various-sized memory blocks that are managed by an allocator
  • dynamically allocated memory: is allocated during runtime to satisfy the uncertain memory needs
block

A continuous chunk of memory containing a payload and overhead

payload

Part of block usable by the process requesting heap memory

overhead

Part of the block used by the allocator to manage the heap’s structure

allocator

Code that allocates and frees blocks as requested by a process

Allocator Approach

  • Implicit: Java
    • new automatically determines block size
    • garbage collector recycles for us
  • Explicit: C
    • malloc: we say how many bytes we needed
    • free is required when we’re done using block

C’s Heap Allocator (stdlib.h)

What’s in the stdlib.h?

A collection of about 25 commonly used C functions

  • conversion (atof, atoi, atol)
  • execution flows (abort, exit)
  • math (abs)
  • searching (bsearch)
  • sorting (qsort)
  • random numbers (rand, srand(seed))
  • allocator functions

Allocator Functions

void *malloc(size_t size)

Allocates and returns generic ptr to block of heap memory of size bytes, or return null if allocation fails, memory double word aligned in Unix

void *calloc(size_t nItems, size_t size)

Allocates, clears to 0, and returns a block of heap memory of nItems*size bytes,

void *realloc(void *ptr, size_t size)

Reallocates to size bytes a previously allocated block of heap memory pointed to by ptr.

if (ptr == null) return malloc(size);
else if (size == 0) {
    free(ptr);
    return null;
}
else // attempt to resize a block
void free(void *ptr)

Frees the heap memory pointed to by ptr

  • If ptr is null, free does nothing.
  • Undefined:
    • free freed heap memory
    • free stack memory

void return type means it can’t tell us if there was a problem

If malloc/calloc/realloc returns null, exit program with an error message.

Posix brk (unistd.h)

What is unistd.h

Header file to access posix (Portable OS Interface)

IEEE CS Standard for maintaining compatibility between Unix OS’s

DIY Heap via Posix Calls

Brk

“Program Break”, a pointer to the top of the heap

int brk(void *addr)

sets the top of the heap to specified address
returns 0 if success, else -1 and sets errno
OS clears to 0 new heap pages

void *sbrk(intptr_t incr)

Attempts to change the program’s top of heap by incr bytes
returns old brk if success, else -1 and sets errno

errno.h

header file to get the error number

printf("Error %s", strerror(errno));

Use malloc/calloc/realloc instead since they will allocate sufficient heap space

item.title: CS540-11 Simulated Annealing
item.description:
Local Search

  • Hill Climbing
  • Simulated Annealing
  • Genetic Algorithm

State Space + successor G = (V,E)
Score f(s), $\forall s \in V $

Hill Climbing (T, S)

  1. at state s, pick a (random) successor t
  2. move to t
    • with probability p if f(t) $\le$ f(s)
    • definitely, if f(t) > f(s)
$p=e^{-\frac{f(s)-f(t)}{T}}$

Simulated Annealing

  1. Randomly choose state s
  2. T = big
  3. s $\leftarrow$ HC(T, s)
  4. Reduce T

T: temperature
Reduce T: cooling scheme (e.g. T $\leftarrow$ a*T, 0 < a < 1)

$T_t = b*c^t$

Genetic Algorithm

State representation (DNA)

  • Start with population of random states
  • treat f score f(s) as the fitness score of the individual
  • select 100 pairs according to probability and fitness
  • Exchange part of DNA to generate two children
  • remove the original 100 population
  • mutation: very small probability to change a DNA at specific position with another random one

item.title: CS354-07 Standard IO
item.description:
Standard and String IO in stdio.h library

Standard IO

Standard Output (console)
putchar, puts
int printf(const char *format, ...)
  • format string, format specifiers
  • matching vars
  • returns the number of chars written of negative if error
Standard Input (console)
getchar, gets
int scanf(const char *format, ...)
  • gets uses EOLN termination
  • format string with info for input format and format specifiers
  • each format specifier must have the address of a matching vars
  • returns the number of inputs that have been successfully matched
Standard Error (console)
void perror(const char *str)

String IO

int sprintf(char *str, const char *format, ...)
// sends formatted output to specified string
int sscanf(const char *str, const char *format, ...)
// gets formatted input from specified string

File I/O in stdio.h Library

Standard I/O Redirection

% a.out < input file > output file

note with output redirection, errors printed with perror still appears on the console terminal

File IO

File Output
fputc/putc, fputs
int fprintf(FILE *stream, const char *format, ...)
File Input
fgetc/getc, ungetc, fgets
int fscanf(FILE *stream, const char *format, ...)

returns the number of inputs or EOF if error or End Of File

File Pointers/Descriptors

stdin, stdout, stderr

printf("Hello");
// Equivalent to
fprintf(stdout, "Hello");
Open/Closing
FILE *fopen(const char *filename, const char *mode)

returns a pointer to the open file or NULL if it can’t access

int fclose(FILE *stream)

returns 0, or EOF if there’s an error

Copying Text Files

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h> // for exit()

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    if (argc != 3) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Usage: copy inputfile outputfile\n");
        exit(1);
    }


    FILE *ifp, *ofp;
    ifp = fopen(argv[1], "r");
    if (ifp == NULL) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Can't open input file %s!\n", argv[1]);
        exit(1);
    }


    ofp = fopen(argv[2], "w");
    if (ofp == NULL) {
        fprintf(stderr, "Can't open output file %s!\n", argv[2]);
        exit(1);
    }


    const int bufsize = 257; // lines assumed to be 256 chars or less
    char buffer[bufsize];

    while (fgets(buffer, bufsize, ifp) != NULL)
        fputs(buffer, ofp);

    fclose(ifp);
    fclose(ofp);


    return 0;
}

What do I live?

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
int gus = 14;
int guy;
int madison(int pam) {
    static int max = 0;
    int meg[] = {22,44,88};
    int *mel = &pam;
    max = gus--;
    return max + meg[1] + *mel;
}
int *austin(int *pat){
    static int amy = 33;
    int *ari = malloc(sizeof(int)*44);
    gus--;
    *ari = *pat;
    return ari;
}
int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    int vic[] = {33,66,99};
    int *wes = malloc(sizeof(int));
    *wes = 55;
    guy = 66;
    free(wes);
    wes = vic;
    wes[1] = madison(guy);
    wes = austin(&gus);
    free(wes);
    printf("Where do I live?");
    return 0;
}
  • Arrays, structs, pointers can live in any memory area (2,3,4,5)

  • Pointer variables can store any address

  • vic[]: 5

  • {33, 66, 99}: 1

  • wes, ari: 5

  • malloc* : 4

  • assignment: 1

  • pam: 5

  • meg: 5

  • gus: 2

  • guy: 3

  • return value: 5

  • max: 3

C Abstract Memory Model

1. CODE Segment (AKA .text & .rodata)

contains: Program instructions and literals

  • typically is read only and sharable

2. Initialized DATA Segment (AKA .data)

What: Memory allocation with a specified size, type, and non-zero initialization. Lifetime: entire program executiton

Contains: extern, global and static local variables that are non-zero initialization

3. Uninitialized DATA Segment (AKA .bss)

What: Memory allocation with a specified size, type and uninitialized or initialized to zero. Lifetime: entire program executiton

Contains: extern, global and static local variables that are uninitialized or initialized to zero

4. HEAP (AKA Free Store)

What: Memory allocation requested during execution.

Lifetime: programmer managed using malloc/free

Contains: Dynamic memory allocations

5. STACK (AKA Call Stack, Auto Store)

What: Memory automatically allocated and freed as functions are executed.

Lifetime: from definition till end of its scope

Contains: Stack frames with non-static local and param variables

LIFO: Last in, first out

Stack Frame: AKA activation record, contains set values for a call of some - later

Virtual Address Space for a Process (IA-32/Linux)

32-bit Processor = 32-bit Addresses

byte addressable

each address accesses 1 bytemax addressable bytes: 2^32 = 4,294,967,296 = 4GB

Virtual address space

illusion by OS that each process has it’s own memory sandbox

Process

Running program

Virtual Address

Simulated address generated by processes

Physical Address

Actual address used to access the machine’s memory

Page table

OS use this to map from virtual addresses to physical addresses

Linux: Processes and Address Spaces

Program Size

%gcc -m32 myProg.c
%size a.out   
text    data     bss     dec     hex filename   
1029     276       4    1309     51d a.out

Virtual Address Space Maps

%cat /proc/<pid_of_process>/maps
%cat /proc/self/maps

Process and Job control

Linux is a multitasking OS where you can concurrently run multiple processes

  • ps: lists a snapshot of your running processes
  • jobs: list a snapshot of the processes you’ve started from the command line
  • &: Puts a process in the background
  • Ctrl-z: Suspend the running foreground process
  • bg: Puts a suspended process in the background
  • fg: Brings the process to the foreground
  • Ctrl-c: Stops a running foreground process
  • kill: Stops a process that is running in background

item.title: CS540-10 Hill Climbing
item.description:
Hill Climbing (greedy)

  • Random restart, keep tracking best local optimum
  • inspect a single neighbor t (current state s)
    • if f(t)>f(s) move to t s $\leftarrow$ t
    • else do nothing

sth

  • if f(t) > f(s) s $\leftarrow t$
  • else [with probability p $\in$ (0,1), s $\leftarrow$ t; otherwise, do nothing]
    • $\uparrow$ pseudo code for else
    • if (random() $\le$ p) s $\leftarrow$ t;
    • else no op

item.title: CS354-06 Structures & Cmdline Arguments
item.description:
Command Line Arguments

What?

Consider the Linux command: %gcc myprog.c -Wall -m32 -std=gnu99 -o myprog

Info entered at the command prompt. Note CLAs start with the prog name and then are followed by prog args.

Why?

Enables info to be passed to the program before it begins execution.

How?

Consider the code:

int main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    for (int i = 0; i < argc; i++)
    printf("%s\n", argv[i]);
}
  • argc: arg count of whitespace separated CLAs
  • argv: arg vector, which is an array of char pointers

Assume the program above is invoked with “a.out eleven 22 -33.3” Draw the memory diagram for argv.

Now show what is output by the program:

a.out
eleven
22
-33.3

Meet Structure

What? A structure defines:

a new data type that is a composite of typically related data of difference kind

Why?

Enables organizing data into a single module.

How?

struct <struct-name> {
    <data-declarations>;
} <optional-list-of-variables>;
// ; end the new type declaration

Declare a structure representing a date having a integer month, day of month, and year.

struct date { // struct is a name space identified with "struct"
    int month;
    int mday;
    int year;
};

Create a variable containing today’s date

struct Date today;
today.month = 9;
today.mday = 26;
today.year = 2017;

dot operator(.): member access operator

Typedef

What?

Defines a new type name in the global name space

Why?

Easier, less cluttered

Update the code above to use typedef

typedef struct {
    int month;
    int mday;
    int year;
} Date;
Date today;
// ...

Nested Structures and Array of Structures

Nested Structures

Add a Date struct, named caught, to the structure code below.

typedef struct { ... } Date; //from previous page
typedef struct {
    char name[12];
    char type[12];
    float weight;
    Date caught;
} Pokemon;
Structures can contain
  • Structures
  • arrays

Nested as deeply as we wish

Show how a pokemon is laid out in the memory diagram

Array of structures

Statically allocate an array, named pokedex, and initialize it with two pokemon.

Pokemon pokedex[2] =
{ { "Abra", "Psych", 43.0, { 1, 21, 2017 } },
  { "Oddish", "bro..", 11.9, { 7, 23, 2017 } } };
Arrays can have

structures for their elements

Structures and functions

Complete the function below that displays the a Date structure.

void printDate (Date date) {
    printf("%d/%d/%d", date.month, date.mday, date.year);
}
Structures are passed

by value which copies the entire structure

Consider the additional code:

//assume Date, Pokemon, printDate code included here
void printPm(Pokemon pm) {
    printf("\nPokemon Name : %s",pm.name);
    printf("\nPokemon Type : %s",pm.type);
    printf("\nPokemon Weight : %f",pm.weight);
    printf("\nPokemon Caught on : ", printDate(pm.caught));
    printf("\n");
}
int main(void) {
    Pokemon pm1 = {"Abra","Psychic",30,{1,21,2017}};
    printPm(pm1);
}

Complete the function below so that it displays pokedex.

void printDex(Pokemon dex[], int size) {
    for (int i = 0; i < size; i++)
        printPM(dex[i]);
}
Arrays are passed

by value but only their address is copied, the elements are not copied.

Pointer to Structures

Why？

  • Enables heap allocation
  • Avoids copying overhead from pass-by-value
  • Allows functions to change their structure args
  • Enables creating linked data structure

How?

Declare a pointer to a Pokemon

Pokemon* pmptr;

Dynamically allocate space for a Pokemon

pmptr = malloc(sizeof(Pokemon));

Assign a weight to the Pokemon

(*pmptr).height = 43.0; // Don't use
pmptr -> height = 43; // Use this

Assign a name and type to the pokemon

strcpy(pmptr->name, "asdf");
strcpy(pmptr->type, "asdf");

Assign a caught date to the Pokemon

pmptr->caught.month = 9;
pmptr->caught.mday = 28;
pmptr->caught.year = 2017;

Deallocate the Pokemon’s memory

free(pmptr);
// pmptr = NULL;

Update printPm to efficiently pass and print a Pokemon.

void printPm(Pokemon *pm) {
    printf("\nPokemon Name : %s",pm->name);
    printf("\nPokemon Type : %s",pm->type);
    printf("\nPokemon Weight : %f",pm->weight);
    printf("\nPokemon Caught on : ");
    printDate(pm->caught);
    printf("\n");
}
int main(void) {
    Pokemon pm1 = {"Abra","Psychic",30,{1,21,2017}};
    printPm(&pm1);
}

item.title: CS540-09 Hill Climbing
item.description:
Score Function f

f(s) $\forall s$

  • f(s) = number of queens attacking each other
  • f(s) = 8 - # of queens attacking

Hill Climbing

Hill Climbing (s)

  • randomly generate s
  • check f(s) (number of queens not attacking)
  • t = succ(s)
  • check f(t), pick the max
  • if $(f(s) < max(f(t)))$ then $s \leftarrow argmax(f) , t \in succ(s)$
  • (argmax returns the arg with max function value)
  • else return s

Local Maximum vs Global Maximum

Hill Climbing may be stuck at Local Maximum

Hill Climbing with Random Restarts

e.g. TSP

item.title: CS540-08 A* Search
item.description:
A* Search

Proof A* finds the optimal path

Support not, A* ends of G’s instead of G
n is the node where it diverges from optimal path
$f(s) = g(s) + h(s)

  1. $f(G’) > f(G)$
  2. $f(n) \ge f(G’)$
  3. $f(n) = g(n) + h(n) \le g(n) + h’(n) = f(G)$ (h is the heuristic, h’ is the true future cost)

1,2,3 $\to$ $f(G) \gt f(G)$ (contradiction)

Improvement

  1. ID A*
  2. Beam search (fix max PQ size)

item.title: CS354-05 Array on the heap
item.description:
1D Arrays on the Heap

What? Memory segments used by a program include

  • Stack vs Heap
  • static allocation vs dynamic
  • during compile time vs runtime

Why? Heap memory enables

  • A program to access more mem than what’s allocated by the compiler
  • Blocks of memory to be allocated and freed in an arbitrary order

How?

#include "stdlib.h"
// for malloc and free

malloc(size_in_mem);
// Preserves a block of heap mem of the specified size

free(pointer);
// Frees the heap mem pointed to by the specified pointer

sizeof(operand);
// operator that returns size in bytes of its operand

  • IA32

    • sizeof(double) = 8
    • sizeof(char) = 1
    • sizeof(int) = 4

  • Write the cdoe to dynamically allocate an integer array named a having 5 elements

    void someFunction() {
int * a = malloc(5 * sizeof(int));
}

  • Draw a memory diagram showing array a

Stack: $\block$ a
$\downarrow$
Heap: |?|?|?|?|?|

  • Write the code that gives the element at indexes 0, 1 and 2 a values of 0, 11 and 22 by using pointer dereferencing, indexing, and address arithmetic respectively.
*a=0;
a[1]=11;
*(a+2)=22;
  • Write the code that uses a pointer named p to give the element at index 3 a value of 33.
int* p = a;
*(p+3) = 33;
  • Write the code that frees array a’s heap memory.
free(a);
a = NULL;

Pointer Caveats

Don’t dereference uninitialized or NULL pointers!

int *p;
*p = 11;
int *q = NULL;
*q = 11;

Don’t dereference freed pointers!

int *p = malloc(sizeof(int));
int *q = p;
. . .
free(p);
. . .
*q = 11;

dangling pointer: is a pointer with an address to heap memory that has been freed

Watch out for memory leaks!

int *p = malloc(sizeof(int));
int *q = malloc(sizeof(int));
. . .
p = q;

Be careful with testing for equality!

assume p and q are pointers

  • p = q compares nothing because it’s assignment
  • p == q compares addresses in pointers
  • * p == * q compares values in pointees

Don’t return addresses of local variables!

int *badcode() {
    int i = 11;
    return &i;
}
int *badMakeIntArray(int size) {
    int a[size];
    return a;
}

2D Arrays on the Heap

Java 2D “Array of Arrays”

int[][] m = new int[2][4];

Allocating on the Heap a 2D “Array of Arrays” in C

  1. Make a 2D array pointer named m (declare a pointer to an integer pointer). int** m;

  2. Assign m an “array of arrays” (allocate of a 1D array of integer pointers of size ROWS). m = malloc(rows * sizeof(int*))

  3. Assign each element in the “array of arrays” it own row of integers (for each row allocate a 1D array of integers of size COLS).

    for (int i=0; i<ROWS; i++)
m[i] = malloc(COLS*sizeof(int));
  • What is the contents of m after the code below executes when ROWS is 2 and COLS is 4?
for (int i = 0; i < ROWS; i++) {
    for (int j = 0; j < COLS; j++)
        m[i][j] = i + j;

  • Can the following be used to replace m[i][j]?

    a.) * ( * (m+i)+j) Yes
    b.) * ( * m + COLS * i + j) No requires a continuous array

  • Write the code to free the heap allocated 2D array?

for (int i =0; u<ROWS; i++)
    free(m[i]);
free(m)

Free the components of your heap memory

In reverse order of their allocation

Array Caveats

Arrays have no bounds checking!

int a[5];
for (int i = 0; i < 11; i++)
    a[i] = 0;

Arrays cannot be return types!

int[] makeIntArray(int size) {
    return malloc(sizeof(int) * size);
}

Not all 2D arrays are alike!

  • What is the layout for 2D arrays on the stack?
  • What is the layout for 2D arrays on the heap?

An array argument must match its parameter!

Statically allocated arrays require all but their first dimension specified!

int a[2][4] = {{1,2,3,4},{5,6,7,8}};
printIntArray(a);
  • Which of the following are type compatible with a ?
void printIntArray(int a[2][4]) { . . . } // Y
void printIntArray(int a[8][4]) { . . . } // Y
void printIntArray(int a[][4]) { . . . } // Y
void printIntArray(int a[4][8]) { . . . } // N Col too big
void printIntArray(int a[][]) { . . . } // N Incomplete type
void printIntArray(int (*a)[4]) { . . . } // Y
void printIntArray(int **a) { . . . } // N

item.title: CS354-04 C String & Arrays
item.description:
Today

  • C String
  • 2D array and pointers

C Strings

What? A String is

  • A sequence of chars whose end is marked with a null char (\0).
  • Represented as a one dimensional array of chars

How?

  • Declare a string variable, named str1 and initialize it with “CS 354”
void someFunction() {
    char str1[11] = "CS 354";
    // Copy the string literal into str1's mem
}
  • Complete the memory diagram of str 1
C S 3 5 4 \0 ? ? ? ?
The identifier of a string

Correspond to address of elem 0.

  • Declare a string pointer, named sptr1, and initialize it with “CS 354”
char *sptr1 = "CS 354";
  • Draw a memory diagram for the code.

sptr1
$\downarrow$

C S 3 5 4 \0

STRING CAVEATS!

  • Assume both code fragments below are added to somefunction above, what happens when the code is attempted to be compiled and run?
  1. str1 = "folderol";
    • Compiler Error
  2. sptr1 = "mumpsimus";
    • No problems

Only string pointer variables can be assigned a new string’s address

String.h

What ? string.h is

  • A collection of useful functionsthat manipulate c strings

int strlen(const char *str)
Returns the length of string str up to but not including the null character.

char *strcpy(char *dest, const char *src)
Copies the string pointed to by src to the memory pointed to by dest and terminates with the null character.

char *strcat(char *dest, const char *src)
Appends the string pointed to by src to the end of the string pointed to by dest and terminates with the null character.

int strcmp(const char *str1, const char *str2)
Compares the string pointed to by str1 to the string pointed to by str2.
Like java,

  • negative if str1 comes before str2
  • 0 if same
  • positive if str1 comes after str2

dest must be large enough to hold result string or buffer overflow

MORE STRING CAVEATS!

  • Assume each code fragments below is added to somefunction on the prior page, what happens when the code is attempted to be compiled and run?
  1. strcpy(str1, "formication");
    • buffer overflow, null char written out of the array
  2. strcpy(sptr1, "vomitory");
    • Compiles, may be the same as $\uparrow$ or segfault if sptr’s memory is read only

Use strcpy (or strncpy) to copy a string into writable memory of another string

Recall 2D array

void someFunction(){
    int m[2][4] = {{0,1,2,3},{4,5,6,7}};
}

m:

0 1 2 3
4 5 6 7
  • What is output by this code fragment?
for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
    for (int j = 0; j < 4; j++) {
        printf("%i", m[i][j]);
    }
    printf("\n");
}

0123
4567

Memory is a sequence of bytes

Statically allocated 2D arrays are allocated as a continuous block of memory in role major order

layout is row by row

2D array and pointers

Address Arithmetic for Statically Allocated 2D Arrays

  • Which of the following are equivalent to m[i][j]?

a. (*(m+i))[j]
- addr arith to row i and index to col j
b. *(m[i]+j)
- index to row i, addr arith to col j
c. *( *(m+i)+j)
- full addr arith

m[i][j] = * ( * (m+i) + j )
  1. Compute row i address
    • start at array’s address
    • add offset to row i; auto scaled by the row size
  2. dereference the address to access row i
  3. compute element j address in row i
    • add offset to col j in row i; auto scaled by elem size
  4. dereference the address to access element in row i column j
m[0][0] = * * m
  • What type is * * m? [int]
  • What type is * m? [int *] = m[0] = addr of start of row
  • What type is m? [int * *] for a statically allocated array 2D
  • * m is the addr of row 0 and * * m is also the addr of row 0
m[i][j]

= * ( * m + cols * i + j )
scaling required for row size

For 2d array in row-major order

item.title: CS540-06 A* Search
item.description:
Edge cost c(s, s’)

Path cost

  • best path from init to s: g(s)
  • best path from s to goal: h(s)
graph LR;
    init --> s1;
    init --> s3;
    init --> s5;
    s1 --> s2;
    s3 --> s4;
    s5 --> s6;
    s2 --3--> s7;
    s4 --2--> s7;
    s6 --1--> s7;
    s7 --> goal;

g(s2) = g(s4) = g(s6) = 2
h(s2) = 4
h(s4) = 3
h(s6) = 2

h(): Heuristic function --> informed search

Priority queue: put g(s)+h(s) instead of g(s)

Ex.

8 1 3
2 4
5 6 7

goal:

1 2 3
4 5 6
7 8

Lower bound for h(s): sum of manhattan distance for all the tiles to get to goal place

$$H(s)= \sum_{t=1}^8 {| r_1^t - r_1^t| + |C_1^t - C_2^t|}$$

A* Search $\uparrow$

  • g(s) + h(s) in priority queue
  • $\forall h(s)$ must be a lower bound of the true h (h is admissible)
  • fail if h is not admissible

item.title: CS354-03 Pointers
item.description:
Today

  • Practive Pointer Basics
  • Recall 1D arrays
  • 1D arrays and pointers
  • Parameters and Pointers

Practice Pointer Basics

void someFunction() {
    int* ptr1, ptr2;
}
How many pointer variables are declared in the code above?

1

  • ptr1 is a pointer
  • ptr2 is an int var
int *ptr1, *ptr2;
What address is stored in ptr1?

DANGER: it’s uninitialized. It may appear to be 0. But it’s actually whatever bit pattern was in the memory.

Write the code to initialize ptr1 with address 0
ptr1 = 0; // or ptr1 = 0x0;
// or
ptr1 = NULL; // must include one of c's standard libraries
Given i below, write the code to make ptr1 point at i
int i = 22;
ptr1 = &i;
Write the code to display ptr1’s pointee’s value
printf("%d\n", *ptr1);
What happens if the code above executes when ptr1 is NULL

Segmentation Fault (Core Dumped)

Write the code to display ptr1’s value
printf("%p\n", ptr1);

It is usually not useful to know a pointer’s exact value, which is why we draw arrows instead.

What does the code below do?
int **q = $ptr1;

it creates a pointer to a pointer to an integer.

Recall 1D arrays

What?

An array variable is

  • A compound unit of storage having parts called elements
  • it’s accessed using its identifier and indexing to get to a particular element
  • stack allocated as a continuous, fixed-size block of memory

Why?

  • For storing a collection of data of the same type with fast access to its elements.
  • Because it’s much easier to declare individual variables

How?

void someFunction() {
    int a[5];
}
How many integer elements have been allocated memory?

5 stack allocated elements

Write the code that gives the element at index 1 a value of 11
a[1] = 11;
Draw a memory diagram showing array a
0 1 2 3 4
? 11 ? ? ?

DANGER: elements are undefined/uninitialized

The name of an array

Correspond to the address of element 0 in C.

1D Array and Pointers

Given:

void someFunction() {
    int a[5];
}

Basic Memory Diagram

0 1 2 3 4
? ? ? ? ?

Linear Memory Diagram

LMD
…
Lower Addr

Address Arithmetic

a[i] $\equiv$ *(a+i)

  1. compute address

    • starts at array name (addr of elem 0)
    • add the offset to elem i, which is automatically scaled for the elem’s size
    • 0x_20 + 2*4 = 0x_20 + 8 = 0x_28
    LMD
    00
    00
    00
    16

  2. dereference computed address to access the element’s value

    • a[i] = *(a+i);
    • or to assign it a value
    • Note ()’s name are required
  • Write the code that uses address arithmetic to give the element at index 2 a value of 22
*(a+2) = 22;
  • Write the code that gives the element at index 0 a value of 0
*a = 0;

Using a pointer

  • Write the code to create a pointer p having the address of element 0 in array a
int *p = a;
  • Now write the code that uses p to give the element in a at index 3 a value of 33
*(p+3) = 33;

Pointers and Arrays are strongly related in C

Parameters and Pointers

What is output by the code below?

void f(int pv1, int *pv2, int *pv3, int pv4[]) {
    int lv = pv1 + *pv2 + *pv3 + pv4[0];
    pv1 = 11;
    *pv2 = 22;
    *pv3 = 33;
    pv4[0] = lv;
    pv4[1] = 44;
}
int main(void) {
    int lv1 = 1, lv2 = 2;
    int *lv3;
    int lv4[] = {4,5,6};
    lv3 = lv4 + 2;
    f(lv1, &lv2, lv3, lv4);
    printf("%i,%i,%i\n",lv1,lv2,*lv3);
    printf("%i,%i,%i\n",lv4[0],lv4[1],lv4[2]);
    return 0;
}

lv: 1, 2, 6, [4,5,6]
f(1, ?, 6, [4, 5, 6])
lv = 1 + 2 + 6 + 4

1 22 33

Call Stack Tracing

  • Manually tracing code with functions in a manner that mimics the machine
  • Each function gets a box when it is called: activation record / stack frame
  • Top box on the stack is executing and those below are suspended waiting for their call-ee to return

Pass/Call-by-value

  • Arg is copied into its corresponding param
  • used with basic types (scalars) since they’re fast to copy

Changing the parameter

Does not change its args

Passing an address argument

  • The arg is copied into its param which must be a pointer
  • used with complex types to avoid copying
  • used to enable functions to change args’s values

A pointer parameter

  • can change its arg by accessing its pointee with dereferencing.

item.description:
Iterative Deepening

  • DFS, stop expanding at level 1, $b^0$
  • DFS, stop expanding at level 2, $b^0 + b^1$
  • …
  • DFS, stop expanding at level b. $b^0 + … + b^d$

Time Complexity: $d*b^0 + (d-1)*b^1 + … + b^{b-1}$

Search Table V2

Guaranteed to find a goal ? Is it the optimal goal ? Time Complexity Space Complexity
BFS Yes Yes (no if cost not the same) $\sum_{x=1}^d b^{d-1} \sim O(b^d)$ $b^d-1 \sim O(b^d)$
DFS No No (m finite) $O(b^m)$ $m*b \sim O(mb)$
UCS Yes Yes $O(b^m)$ $O(b^m)$
ID Yes Yes $O(b^d)$ $O(b*d)$

So far, every search algorithm is Uninformed Search

Graph is not a tree

C Programming Language

  • Parameter: VARIABLE where the argument is stored in the called func

Return-by-value

C Control Flow

Sequencing

Evaluation

Like java

Which value means true? true? 42? -17? 0?

dangling else

Like java, but not with strings

Like java

for varieble in for to behave like java, use compiler flags -std=gnu99

Recall Variables

What?

A scalar variable is AKA primitives

A single unit of storage whose contents can change.

Aspects of a variable

  • Identifier: name associated with var’s address
  • value: Info stored in var’s memory
  • address: Location in memory of the variable
  • type: how to interpret the pattern of bits in a var’s memory, e.g. signed ints are in two’s complement.
  • size: Number of butes needed to store a specific type, e.g. int is 4 bytes
  • endianess: the ordering of bytes for a type > 4 bytes
    • little endian: we’ll use least significant digits are at the lowest address
    • big endian: the opposite

Base 10: 11
Base 2 : 0000 0000 … 0000 1011
Base 16: 0 0 … 0 B
0x0000000B

Meet pointers

What?

A pointer variable is

  • a unit of storage whose contents is a memory address of a var, func, device, …
  • like java references but require they require more syntax and knowledge to use correctly

Why?

  • for indirect memory access (Thur.)
  • for indirect access to funcs (later)
  • because they are used extensively in c libraries & OS code
  • for access to memory mapped hardware

How?

void someFunction()
{
 int i = 11;
 int *ptr = NULL;
 ptr = &i;
 *ptr = 22;
}

What’s the ptr’s

  • Initial value? NULL 0x00000000
  • Address? 0x00000004
  • Type? int*
  • Size? 4 Bytes

Pointer: does the pointing (at address tail), declared using *
pointee: is pointed at (at address head)
address of: & operater, which returns its operands addr
dereferencing: using * operater to access a pointer’s pointee indirectly

item.title: CS252-03 Binary System
item.description:
Computer is a binary digital system.

Digital system: finite number of symbols
Binary (base two) system: has two states: 0 and 1

Basic unit of information is the binary digit, or bit
Values with more than two states require multiple bits.

  • A collection of two bits has four possible states: 00, 01, 10, 11.
  • A collection of three bit has eight possible states.
  • A collection of n bits has $2^n$ possible states.

CPU and Memory - Data Bus, Address Bus

graph TD;
    Address Bus --> Memory;
    Address Bus --> I/O;
    Memory --> CPU;
    CPU --> Memory;
    Memory --> I/O;
    I/O --> Memory;
    CPU --> Address Bus;
    Data Bus <--> CPU;
    Data Bus <--> Memory;
    Data Bus <--> I/O;

What kinds of data do we need to represent?

Numbers, Text, Image, Sound, Logical, Instructions …

Data Type

  • Representation and operations within the computer

Signed Integers

With n bits, we have 2^n distint values - Assign about half to positive integers and half to negative - that leaves two values: one for 0, and one extra

Positive Integers

  • Just like unsigned - zero in most significant bit
  • 00101 = 5

Negative integers

  • sign-magnitute - set top bit to show negative, other bits are the same as unsigned
    • 10101 = -5
  • one’s complement - flip every bit to represent negative

Two’s complement

Problems with sign-magnitube and 1’s complement

  • two representation of 0 (+0 and -0)
  • arithmetic circuits are complex

Two’s complement representation developed to make circuits easy for arithmatic.

  • for each positive number X, assign value to its negative such that X + (-X) =0 with normal addition, ignoring carry out

two’s complement representation

If number is positive or zero,

  • normal binary representation, zeroes in upper bit(s)

If number is negative,

  • start with positive number
  • flip every bit (take the one’s complement)
  • then add one

Two’s complement signed integers

MS bit is sign bit - it has weight - 2^n-1

Range of an n-bit number: -2^n-1 through 2^n-1 -1

Integer representation schemes

  • Computers use a fixed number of bits to represent an integer
    • 8 bit, 16-bit, 32-bit, 64-bit
  • There are two representation schemes for integers:
    • Unsigned integers: can represent zero and positive integers
    • Signed Integers: can represent zero, positive and negative integers. Three

Sign-Magnitude representation

  • if the sign bit is 0 --> the number is positive in value.
  • if the sign bit is 1 --> the number is negative in value.

item.title: Psych202-Exam02 Review
item.description:
Terminology

2 Research Methodology

2.1 Scientific Method

data

Measurable outcomes of research studies.

research

A scientific process that involves the careful collection of data.

scientific method

A systematic and dynamic procedure of observing and measuring phenomena, used to achieve the goals of description, prediction, control, and explanation; it involves an interaction among research, theories, and hypotheses.

theory

A model of interconnected ideas or concepts that explains what is observed and makes predictions about future events. Theories are based on empirical evidence.

hypothesis

A specific, testable prediction, narrower than the theory it is based on.

replication

Repetition of a research study to confirm the results.

2.2 Types of studies

variable

Something in the world that can vary and that a researcher can manipulate (change), measure (evaluate), or both.

independent variable

The variable that gets manipulated in a research study.

dependent variable

The variable that gets measured in a research study.

operational definition

A definition that qualifies (describes) and quantifies (measures) a variable so the variable can be understood objectively.

descriptive research

Research methods that involve observing behavior to describe that behavior objectively and systematically.

case study

A descriptive research method that involves the intensive examination of an unusual person or organization.

participant observation

A type of descriptive study in which the researcher is involved in the situation.

naturalistic observation

A type of descriptive study in which the researcher is a passive observer, separated from the situation and making no attempt to change or alter ongoing behavior.

reactivity

The phenomenon that occurs when knowledge that one is being observed alters the behavior being observed.

experimenter expectancy effect

Actual change in the behavior of the people or nonhuman animals being observed that is due to the expectations of the observer.

self-report methods

Methods of data collection in which people are asked to provide information about themselves, such as in surveys or questionnaires.

correlational studies

A research method that describes and predicts how variables are naturally related in the real world, without any attempt by the researcher to alter them or assign causation between them.

positive correlation

A relationship between two variables in which both variables either increase or decrease together.

negative correlation

A relationship between two variables in which one variable increases when the other decreases.

zero correlation

A relationship between two variables in which one variable is not predictably related to the other.

directionality problem

A problem encountered in correlational studies; the researchers find a relationship between two variables, but they cannot determine which variable may have caused changes in the other variable.

third variable problem

A problem that occurs when the researcher cannot directly manipulate variables; as a result, the researcher cannot be confident that another, unmeasured variable is not the actual cause of differences in the variables of interest.

experiment

A research method that tests causal hypotheses by manipulating and measuring variables.

experimental group

The participants in an experiment who receive the treatment.

control group

The participants in an experiment who receive no intervention or who receive an intervention that is unrelated to the independent variable being investigated.

confound

Anything that affects a dependent variable and that may unintentionally vary between the experimental conditions of a study.

population

Everyone in the group the experimenter is interested in.

sample

A subset of a population.

random assignment

Placing research participants into the conditions of an experiment in such a way that each participant has an equal chance of being assigned to any level of the independent variable.

selection bias

In an experiment, unintended differences between the participants in different groups; it could be caused by nonrandom assignment to groups.

culturally sensitive research

Studies that take into account the role that culture plays in determining thoughts, feelings, and actions.

2.3 Ethic governing psychological research

institutional review boards

(IRBs) Groups of people responsible for reviewing proposed research to ensure that it meets the accepted standards of science and provides for the physical and emotional well-being of research participants.

2.4 How are data analyzed and evaluated

construct validity

The extent to which variables measure what they are supposed to measure.

external validity

The degree to which the findings of a study can be generalized to other people, settings, or situations.

internal validity

The degree to which the effects observed in an experiment are due to the independent variable and not confounds.

reliability

The degree to which a measure is stable and consistent over time.

accuracy

The degree to which an experimental measure is free from error.

descriptive statistics

Statistics that summarize the data collected in a study.

central tendency

A measure that represents the typical response or the behavior of a group as a whole.

mean

A measure of central tendency that is the arithmetic average of a set of numbers.

median

A measure of central tendency that is the value in a set of numbers that falls exactly halfway between the lowest and highest values.

mode

A measure of central tendency that is the most frequent score or value in a set of numbers.

variability

In a set of numbers, how widely dispersed the values are from each other and from the mean.

standard deviation

A statistical measure of how far away each value is, on average, from the mean.

scatterplot

A graphical depiction of the relationship between two variables.

correlation coefficient

A descriptive statistic that indicates the strength of the relationship between two variables.

inferential statistics

A set of assumptions and procedures used to evaluate the likelihood that an observed effect is present in the population from which the sample was drawn.

meta-analysis

A “study of studies” that combines the findings of multiple studies to arrive at a conclusion.

6 Learning

6.1 How do we learn

learning

A relatively enduring change in behavior, resulting from experience.

nonassociative learning

Responding after repeated exposure to a single stimulus, or event.

associative learning

Linking two stimuli, or events, that occur together.

observational learning

Acquiring or changing a behavior after exposure to another individual performing that behavior.

habituation

A decrease in behavioral response after repeated exposure to a stimulus.

sensitization

An increase in behavioral response after exposure to a stimulus.

6.2 How do we learn predictive associations

classical conditioning

(Pavlovian conditioning) A type of associative learning in which a neutral stimulus comes to elicit a response when it is associated with a stimulus that already produces that response.

unconditioned response (UR)

A response that does not have to be learned, such as a reflex.

unconditioned stimulus (US)

A stimulus that elicits a response, such as a reflex, without any prior learning.

conditioned stimulus (CS)

A stimulus that elicits a response only after learning has taken place.

conditioned response (CR)

A response to a conditioned stimulus; a response that has been learned.

acquisition

The gradual formation of an association between the conditioned and unconditioned stimuli.

extinction

A process in which the conditioned ponse is weakened when the conditioned stimulus is repeated without the unconditioned stimulus.

spontaneous recovery

A process in which a previously extinguished conditioned response reemerges after the presentation of the conditioned stimulus.

stimulus generalization

Learning that occurs when stimuli that are similar but not identical to the conditioned stimulus produce the onditioned response.

stimulus discrimination

A differentiation between two similar stimuli when only one of them is consistently associated with the unconditioned stimulus.

Rescorla-Wagner model

A cognitive model of classical conditioning; it holds that the strength of the CS-US association is determined by the extent to which the unconditioned stimulus is unexpected.

phobia

An acquired fear that is out of proportion to the real threat of an object or of a situation.

6.3 How does operant conditioning change behavior

operant conditioning

(instrumental conditioning) A learning process in which the consequences of an action determine the likelihood that it will be performed in the future.

law of effect

Thorndike’s general theory of learning: Any behavior that leads to a “satisfying state of affairs” is likely to occur again, and any behavior that leads to an “annoying state of affairs” is less likely to occur again.

reinforcer

A stimulus that follows a response and increases the likelihood that the response will be repeated.

shaping

A process of operant conditioning; it involves reinforcing behaviors that are increasingly similar to the desired behavior.

positive reinforcement

The administration of a stimulus to increase the probability of a behavior’s being repeated.

negative reinforcement

The removal of an unpleasant stimulus to increase the probability of a behavior’s being repeated.

continuous reinforcement

A type of learning in which behavior is reinforced each time it occurs.

partial reinforcement

A type of learning in which behavior is reinforced intermittently.

partial-reinforcement

extinction effect The greater persistence of behavior under partial reinforcement than under continuous reinforcement.

positive punishment

The administration of a stimulus to decrease the probability of a behavior’s recurring.

negative punishment

The removal of a stimulus to decrease the probability of a behavior’s recurring.

behavior modification

The use of operant-conditioning techniques to eliminate unwanted behaviors and replace them with desirable ones.

cognitive map

A visual/spatial mental representation of an environment.

latent learning

Learning that takes place in the absence of reinforcement.

6.4 How does watching others affect learning

modeling

The imitation of observed behavior.

vicarious learning

Learning the consequences of an action by watching others being rewarded or punished for performing the action.

mirror neurons

Neurons in the brain that are activated when one observes another individual engage in an action and when one performs a similar action.

12 Social Psychology

12.1 How does group membership affect people

social psychology

The study of how people influence other people’s thoughts, feelings, and actions.

outgroup homogeneity effect

The tendency to view outgroup members as less varied than ingroup members.

social identity theory

The idea that ingroups consist of individuals who perceive themselves to be members of the same social category and experience pride through their group membership.

ingroup favoritism

The tendency for people to evaluate favorably and privilege members of the ingroup more than members of the outgroup.

Social facilitation

The idea that the presence of others generally enhances performance.

deindividuation

A state of reduced individuality, reduced self-awareness, and reduced attention to personal standards; this phenomenon may occur when people are part of a group.

group polarization

The process by which initial attitudes of groups become more extreme over time.

groupthink

The tendency of groups to make bad decisions when the group is under pressure, facing external threats, and is biased.

social loafing

The tendency for people to not work as hard in a group than when working alone.

conformity

The altering of one’s behaviors and opinions to match those of other people or to match other people’s expectations.

normative influence

The tendency for people to conform in order to fit in with the group.

informational influence

The tendency for people to conform when they assume that the behavior of others represents the correct way to respond.

social norms

Expected standards of conduct, which influence behavior.

compliance

The tendency to agree to do things requested by others.

foot-in-the-door effect

The idea that if people agree to a small request, they become more likely to comply with a large and undesirable request.

obedience

When a person follows the orders of a person of authority.

12.2 Agression

aggression

Any behavior that involves the intention to harm another.

prosocial behaviors

Actions that tend to benefit others, such as doing favors or helping.

altruism

Providing help when it is needed, without any apparent reward for doing so.

inclusive fitness

An explanation for altruism that focuses on the adaptive benefit of transmitting genes, such as through kin selection, rather than focusing on individual survival.

bystander intervention effect

The failure to offer help by those who observe someone in need when other people are present.

12.3 Attitudes

attitudes

People’s evaluations of objects, of events, or of ideas.

mere exposure effect

The idea that greater exposure to a stimulus leads to greater liking for it.

explicit attitudes

Attitudes that a person can report.

implicit attitudes

Attitudes that influence a person’s feelings and behavior at an unconscious level.

cognitive dissonance

An uncomfortable mental state resulting from a contradiction between two attitudes or between an attitude and a behavior.

persuasion

The active and conscious effort to change an attitude through the transmission of a message.

elaboration likelihood model

The idea that persuasive messages lead to attitude changes in two ways: via the central route or via the peripheral route.

12.4 How do people think about others

nonverbal behavior

The facial expressions, gestures, mannerisms, and movements by which one communicates with others.

attributions

People’s explanations for why events or actions occur.

personal attributions

Explanations of people’s behavior that refer to their internal characteristics, such as abilities, traits, moods, or efforts.

situational attributions

Explanations of people’s behavior that refer to external events, such as the weather, luck, accidents, or other people’s actions.

fundamental attribution error

In explaining other people’s behavior, the tendency to overemphasize personality traits and underestimate situational factors.

prejudice

Negative feelings, opinions, and beliefs associated with a stereotype.

discrimination

The inappropriate and unjustified treatment of people as a result of prejudice.

modern racism

Subtle forms of prejudice that coexist with the rejection of racist beliefs.

12.5 What determines the quality of relationships

passionate love

A state of intense longing and desire.

companionate love

A strong commitment based on friendship, trust, respect, and intimacy.

item.title: Math240-13
item.description:
Venn Diagrams

u: universal set: all object

A,B are sets

Terminalogy

Def: A is a subset of B($a \subseteq b$) if $\forall x (x \in A \to x \in B)$

To Show A $\subseteq$ B

Show that if x belongs to A, then x belongs to B

Ex. Show that the set of multiples of 4 is a subset of the even numbers
Converse: To show $A \subsetneq B$, find a single x $\in$ A not in B

Thm. If S is a set then $\varnothing \subseteq S$ and $S \subseteq S$

Def: A is a proper subset of B $A \subset B$ if $A \subseteq B$ and $\exists x (x \in B \land x \notin A)$

Def: A = B if $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq A$

Size of a set

Def: If there are exactly n distinct elements in S, then S is said to be finite with cardinality n, (|s|=n).
Def: S is infinite if it is not finite

PowerSets

Def: given set S, the power set of S is the set of S is the set of all subsets, denoted P(S)

Ex. $P(\varnothing) =$ {$\varnothing$}

If |S| = n, |P(S)| = $2^n$

Cartisian Product of sets

ordered n tuples (a1, a2, a3, …, an)

Ex. (a,b) $\ne$ (B,a) unless a=b

Def:The cartesian product of A&B is the set
$A \times B = $ {(a,b) | $(a \in A) \land (b \in B)$}

Def: A subset R $\subseteq$ A $\times$ B is called a relation from A to B

Notation

$\forall x (x \in S \to P(x))$, write $\forall x \in S P(x)$

Given P a predicate with domain D, the truth set of P is {x $\in$ D | P(X)}

Ex. The set of even numbers {x $\in$ Z | x=2n $\land$ ($n \in Z$)}

Union Set

Def: Union $A \cup B$ = {x| $x \in A \lor x \in B$}

Def: Intersection $A \cap B$ = {x | $x \in A \land x \in B$}

Def: Difference $A - B$ = {x | $x in A \land x \notin B$}

Def: Complement $\bar A = U-A$

item.title: Math240-10
item.description:
Thm. n = ab, then $a \le \sqrt{n} \, or \, b \le \sqrt{n}$

Thm. if $n^2$ is odd, then n is odd (last time we proved the converse directly)
First Try direct argument
Assume $n^2$ is odd, i.e. $n^2=2k+1$, so $n=sqrt{2k+1}$. (Abandoned)
2nd try, prove contrapositive.
Assume n not odd, i.e. n is even, and show that $n^2$ is even.
If n even, n=2k for suck k, so, $n^2 = (2k)^2 = 2*(2k^2)$

Recall

A contradiction is a proposition that is always false.

Prove by contradiction

Suppose we want p. Suppose there is a contradiction $q \equiv F$ s.t. $\lnot p \rightarrow q$ is true . This means $\lnot p$ is false, this means p is true

Basic example:
Thm. if 3n+2 is odd, then n is odd
Prove by contradiction
Assume the theorem is false. $\lnot (p \rightarrow q) \equiv p \land \lnot q$ which means 3n+2 is odd and n is even. n=2l for some l. Then 3(2l) + 2 is odd. But 3(2l)+2 = 2(3l+1) is even. This is contradiction.

Thm. $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational. (A number is rational if r = $\frac {a}{b}$ for integers a,b)
Proof. Suppose the theorem is false. So $\sqrt {2} = \frac{a}{b}$.
Assume (as we may) that $\frac {a}{b}$ is in lowest terms,
i.e. a and b have no common factors.
$2 = \frac {a^2}{b^2} \rightarrow 2b^2 = a^2$, so $a^2$ is even , so a is even. a = 2c, for some c.
$2b^2 = 4c^2 \rightarrow b^2 = 2c^2$, so b is even.
So a and b are not the lowest terms.

item.title: Psych202-Exam01 Review
item.description:
What is psychology

What is Psychology and how is it useful to us?

  • The scientific study of the structure and causes of:
    • Mind (mental activity)
    • Brain (consider the mind/body problem)
    • Behavior (observable actions)
  • Measurements of ideas is central to psychological science
  • Psychology is a interdisciplinary science
  • Psychology can help us create well-being and happiness

What is Personality Psychology?

The study of characteristic thoughts, emotions, and behaviors in people and how they vary across social situations.

Current perspective to look at during the semester

//TODO: fix this

  1. Psychodynamic
    • Emphasize unconscious and dynamic process
  2. Humanistic
  3. Cognitive
  4. Behavior
  5. Psychobiological

Freud Typographical (iceburg) Model

Freud believed that conscious awareness was only a small fraction of mental activity. That is, conscious awareness represented the proverbial tip of the iceberg, with most mental processes buried under the surface.

The conscious level consists of the thoughts that people are aware of. The preconscious level consists of content that is not currently in awareness but that could be brought to awareness. This level is roughly analogous to long-term memory. The unconscious level contains material that the mind cannot easily retrieve, including hidden memories, wishes, desires, and motives.

Freud Structural Model

Identify the features of this model and how they overlap with the iceberg model

Terms

id: In psychodynamic theory, the component of personality that is completely submerged in the unconscious and operates according to the pleasure principle.

superego: In psychodynamic theory, the internalization of societal and parental standards of conduct.

ego: In psychodynamic theory, the component of personality that tries to satisfy the wishes of the id while being responsive to the dictates of the superego.

In this model, personality consists of three interacting structures, and these structures vary in their access to consciousness. The relative strengths of these structures are primarily responsible for an individual’s personality.

The first structure, the id, exists at the most basic level: completely submerged in the unconscious. The id operates according to the pleasure principle, which directs the person to seek pleasure and to avoid pain.

The second structure, the superego, acts as a brake on the id. Largely unconscious, the superego develops in childhood and is the internalization of parental and societal standards of conduct. It is a rigid structure of morality, or conscience.

The third structure, the ego, mediates between the id and the superego. That is, the ego tries to satisfy the wishes of the id while being responsive to the dictates of the superego. The ego operates according to the reality principle, which involves rational thought and problem solving. Some aspects of the ego’s operations are open to conscious awareness.

Freud Psychosexual Model

psychosexual stages According to Freud, developmental stages that correspond to distinct libidinal urges; progression through these stages profoundly affects personality.

In each psychosexual stage, libido is focused on one of the erogenous zones: the mouth, the anus, or the genitals. The oral stage lasts from birth to approximately 18 months. During this time, infants seek pleasure through the mouth. Because hungry infants experience relief when they breast-feed, they come to associate pleasure with sucking. When children are 2 to 3 years old, they enter the anal stage. During this time, toilet training—learning to control the bowels—leads them to focus on the anus. From age 3 to 5, children are in the phallic stage. That is, they direct their libidinal energies toward the genitals. Children often discover the pleasure of rubbing their genitals during this time, although they have no sexual intent per se. The phallic stage is followed by a brief latency stage. During this time, children suppress libidinal urges or channel them into doing schoolwork or building friendships. Finally, in the genital stage, adolescents and adults attain mature attitudes about sexuality and adulthood. They center their libidinal urges on the capacities to reproduce and to contribute to society.

Page 559 (606 / 862)

Defense Mechanisms

defense mechanisms: Unconscious mental strategies that the mind uses to protect itself from anxiety.

Purposes of defense mechanisms

Conflicts between the id and the superego lead to anxiety. The ego then copes with anxiety through various defense mechanisms: unconscious mental strategies that the mind uses to protect itself from distress.

Personality

Define personality in your own word

What are constructs and how are they measured

Constructs are theoretical-hypothetical ideas for which we seek evidence via the scientific method

  • Our scientific measures yield scores on “variables”
  • Statistically, scores on variables are distributed across a range of values with a:
    • Mean
    • Average
    • Standard Deviation

Personality Tests

Subjective vs. Objective tests:

Projective measures: Personality tests that examine unconscious processes by having people interpret ambiguous stimuli. It explores the unconscious by having people describe or tell stories about ambiguous stimulus items. This general idea is that people will project their mental contents onto the ambiguous items.

Objective measures: Self-Reports

  1. Standardization of items and conditions of measurement
  2. Development of quantitative “norms”
  3. Reliability
  4. Validity
Nomothetic vs. Idiographic approaches to personality psychology

Idiographic Approaches
Person-centered approaches to assessing personality; they focus on individual lives and how various characteristics are integrated into unique person.

Nomothetic Approaches
Approaches to assessing personality that focus on how common characteristics vary from person to person.

What is a personality trait

Traits are internal, stable (i.e. reliable), dispositional characteristics which reflect the “individual’s distinct and relatively enduring pattern of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors”

Traits affect our:

  • Cognition (thoughts)
  • Affect (feelings)
  • Actions (behaviors)

What tests did we take? What do they tell us? Why are the results/conclusions important?

//TODO: finish this

LOT-R
Attributional Style Questionnaire
Defensive Pessimism Questionnaire
UCLA-Loneliness
The Five Factor Model (The Big Five)
Self-Efficacy

What Does Personality have to do with Happiness?

//TODO: find this

Can you change your personality?

Personality traits are relatively stable over time

Eysenck’s 2-factor model and the 4 “temperaments” from Ancient Greece

The inner quadrant of the Eysenk model shows an Ancient Greek Typology that divided people into four types:

  • melancholic (moody and withdrawn)
  • choleric (irritable and outgoing)
  • sanguine (stable and outgoing)
  • phlegmatic (stable and withdrawn)

The “Big Five” (each trait exists on a high/low scale) is perhaps the most dominant current psychometric measurement perspective in personality psychology The following slide describes the poles (High vs. Low on each trait) of the Big-5:

High Low

  • Neuroticism
  • Extraversion
  • Openness
  • Agreeableness
  • Conscientiousness

Think “CANOE” to remember

Re-visiting the Hierarchical View of Extraversion in Eysenk and the Big-5

Big-5 Extraversion Subordinate Trait Level:
  • Friendliness;
  • Gregariousness;
  • Assertiveness;
  • Activity Level;
  • Excitement-Seeking;
  • Cheerfulness.
Big-5 Neuroticism Subordinate Trait Level:
  • Anxiety;
  • Anger;
  • Depression;
  • Self-Consciousness;
  • Immoderation;
  • Vulnerability.

Stress reactivity

“Stress-reactivity” is an individual difference factor, a predisposing “Trait”
some people may be more disposed to perceive events as hassles
some people are more disposed to experience major stressful events

Optimism

//TODO: definition

What personality tests measure this?

//TODO: find it

Optimism is associated with what findings
  1. less illness symptoms in college and beyond
  2. more active approach to stress and problem solving
  3. higher levels of academic success and performance
  4. more likely to complete treatment programs for alcoholism
  5. more likely to make quick, full recovery from coronary bypass surgery
  6. Immune system functioning of optimists is higher
  7. Optimists respond to stressors with smaller increases in blood pressure
  8. Cardiac patients with minimal optimism (higher “hopelessness”) have higher rates of new heart attacks and are twice as likely to die than persons with low hopelessness (as seen in next figure).

Self-Efficacy

Self-Efficacy is the expectation that your efforts will ead to success. This expectation helps mobilize your energies. If you have low self-efficacy - that is, if you do not believe your efforts will pay off - you may be too discouraged even to study. People with high self-efficacy often set challenging goals that lead to success. Sometimes, however, people whose self-views are inflated set goals that they cannot possibly achieve. Again, goals that are challenging but not overwhelming are usually most conducive to success.

Which Psychology professor is associated with this

Albert Bandura

Which personality test is associated with this

Hardiness

“hardiness” is a trait of people who demonstrate:

  • commitment (sense of purpose/involvement with work and family)
  • challenge (openness to new experiences and desire to embrace them)
  • control (belief that one has power to influence important future outcomes—high “self-efficacy” and low “learned helplessness”)

Appraisal Style

//TODO: Find the definition

Appraisal of Challenge and Control:

  • hardy people experience less stressful hassles
  • hardy people also respond to threat and challenge with less physiological stress
  • Optimism, Self-Efficacy, and Hardiness reflect Low Stress-Reactivity
  • Pessimistic, Low Self-Efficacy, Low Hardiness, and Highly Neurotic and Disagreeable persons have higher Stress-Reactivity
  • High Stress-reactivity is correlated with diverse symptoms of psychopathology, mental disorder, personal distress, and reduced physical health

Stress

What is stress

Stress: A type of response that typically involves an unpleasant state, such as anxiety or tension

Stressor: Something in the environment that is perceived as threatening or demanding and therefore produces stress

Coping response: Any attempt made to avoid, escape from, or minimize a stressor.

Types of stressors

  • External stressors: e.g., loss of job, relationship problems, classes not going well…
  • Internal stressors: e.g., chronic self criticism/depressive thinking/social anxiety/hostility etc (i.e., unstable emotionality or “neuroticism”), chronic circulating stress-hormones (dysregulated HPA Axis)

Two Classes of “objective” stressors

  1. Major life events
  2. Daily hassles
  • Class generated List of Daily Hassles:
  • Research shows Objective Effects:
    -people with large #’s of hassles are more emotionally distressed
  • Stressful Life Events affect us through the daily hassles they produce

How do these two types of stressors interact?

//TODO: Find it

Are stressors always negative and yield negative outcomes?

//TODO: Find it

Social Readjustment Rating Scale (Holmes and Rahe)

Hans Selye’s General Adaptation Syndrome (GAS)

  1. Alarm
  2. Resistance
  3. Exhaustion

Is stress a subjective, internal or objective, external response?

Stress is Objective AND Subjective, Internal AND External

Are individual stress reactions concrete and unchangeable?

//TODO: find it

How does personality relate to stress?

//TODO: find it

HPA-Axis

Integrate Seyle’s GAS model with the HPA-axis

//TODO: find how to do it

What does chronically high levels of stress/cortisol do to people?

  • Physiological production of stress-hormones (e.g., adrenaline, cortisol)
  • Negative cognitive appraisals (perception of harm and threat)
  • Behavioral habits non-conducive to health (patterns of sleep, eating, drug and alcohol use, physical activity, maladaptive recruitment of social support)
  • Emotional habits/tendencies toward emotional instability-Neuroticism/over-reactivity (chronic irritability, anger, guilt, worry)

Impact of Stressors depends on Individual Differences

  1. Appraisal
    • Primary stress appraisal processes vs. secondary stress appraisal processes:
  2. Coping
    • Problem solving approaches
    • Emotion Focused coping

Consider different persons responses to:

  • Divorce
  • Sudden Unemployment
  • Disease-onset

All Life-Events Represent Potential Stressors and are “Appraised”

3 kinds of appraisals are possible to challenge:

  1. Harm (a damaging event has occurred)
  2. Threat (a potential future harm is appraised as approaching)
  3. Challenge (events appraised as opportunities rather than threats)

Harm and Threat Appraisals induce psychological stress

Perception $\rightarrow$ Appraisal $\rightarrow$ Emotions/Coping:

Coping, and negative emotions, and “stress-reactivity” depend heavily on:

  • the personality (cognitive-style and trait organization) of the perceiver
  • the non-personality produced mental and behavioral habits of the perceiver (stress-management styles and skills)

Stress Management

Can we change our reaction to stress?

Stress is both a Response and a Process of Adjustment

Stress-reactions are not static! They are continually, dynamically produced as functions of cognitive re-appraisal, behavioral coping, and emotional re-processing.

We appraise all events, and in so-appraising we express core personality traits

(levels of optimism, self-efficacy, hardiness, neuroticism, agreeableness, stress-reactivity, etc.)

Can you alter your personality in order to improve your vulnerability to stress and stressors?

Personality traits that create vulnerability to stress-reactions {e.g. low self-efficacy, low optimism, high pessimism, high neuroticism, high stress-reactivity} can be modulated* with concentrated focus on behavioral and emotional health.

(balanced living through exercise and intake; healthy relationships; consistent efforts to examine and modify negative mental habits of appraisal and emotional processing)

MBSRP

Mindfulness Based Stress Reduction Program:

Mindfully Notice your sensory-physical experience:

  • Pleasant Events
  • Unpleasant Events
  • What bodily sensations and thoughts attend the experiences?

Practice-Actualize Mindful Attitudes in daily life:

  • Acceptance
  • Trust
  • Patience
  • Non-judgment
  • Letting-Go
  • Beginner’s Mind
  • Non-Striving (but not goal-less-ness!!)

Describe how mindfulness of unpleasant events might alter one’s experience of negativity, and how mindfulness of pleasant events might alter one’s experience of positivity.
//TODO:
Discuss how mindfulness influences happiness by affecting appraisal and coping processes.
//TODO

Memory

What is an engram?

The historical term for the elusive “physical trace” of memory(LTM)
Physical reality of Memory: Memories make lasting alterations in structure and function of Central Nervous System. Psychologists have called these physical traces of memory “Engrams”.

Types of engrams or memory traces

  • Procedural Knowledge or Memory (what you know how to do in behavior)
  • Semantic or Declarative Knowledge or Memory (what you know, as verbally represented)
  • Episodic Memory (recollection of experiences, (stories, another type of verbal or declarative knowledge process)

engrams determine your personal perspective to life

Karl Lashley’s Experiment

Karl Lashley trained rats to learn mazes, then removed different areas of cortex, the rats forget how to do the maze almost the same.

His Conclusion: memory is not localized in any specific area of brain (implication: memories are distributed across areas of cortex).

Richard Thompson’s Experiment

Richard Thompson’s work with rabbits suggests simple memories may be localized rather precisely.
He maps the electrical activity of nerve cells that relate to an actual learned behavior as demonstrated in a particular classical conditioning process.

Terms
  • UCS: Unconditional Stimulus
  • UCR: Unconditional Response
  • CS: Conditional Stimulus
  • CR: Conditional Response
Identify
  • UCS: Air puff
  • UCR: Eye Blink
  • CS: The Tone
  • CR: trained eye closure response
Where was the CR stored?

Thompson’s A: Interpositis nucleus, a cubic millimeter of tissue in the cerebellum.

After surgery, the memory for the learned response is completely obliterated; all that is left is the reflex response (which is what?), the same reponse shown before learning ; destroying that tissue permanently abolished the memory for the learned response.

Greenough’s 1st Experiment

  • IV: Enriched environment | impoverished environment
  • DV: dendritic fields, neural connections …
  • Result: Rats in enriched has More dendritic fields, more neural connections, a richer blood supply, an increasing number of supportive glial cells
  • Conclusion:

Greenough’s 2nd Experiment

  • IV: Learning | Exercise
  • DV: density of blood vessels | number of connections
  • Results: Exercising increase the density of blood vessels but not number of connections. Learning increases the number of connections but not the density of blood vessels
  • Conclusions: These two are independent processes. Different demand placed on the brain will cause the brain to either change its wiring diagram or its blood supply.

Memory as Information Processing

Types of Memory

1. Sensory Memory

Sensory Memory stores a brief copy (< 3 seconds) of stimuli that register during sensory processing (product of transduction)
  • Iconic Memory is a transduced/encoded visual snapshot or “icon” and lasts < 1 second (image)
  • Echoic Memory seems to last for at least several seconds (sound)

2. Short Term Memory (STM); AKA Working Memory

STM requires attention, and has limited capacity

STM stores 7 (+/-2) noticed items for up to 30 seconds (longer with “rote” or “maintenance” rehearsal).

Chunking increases STM capacity; experts “chunk,” bits of information, as do successful learners at all levels;

Chunking facilitates encoding and transfer to LTM (facilitates “consolidation” of information in STM into LTM)

3. Long Term Memory (LTM): Our Enduring Recollection of Recent and Remote Past

Types of LTM’s:
  • Explicit/Declarative
  • Implicit/Non-declarative
Explicit or Declarative LTM’s

Explicit Memories are accessible to consciousness, we can talk about them (they can be “declared” consciously). Includes:

  • episodic memory of one’s own specific past experiences and major epidodes of knowledge from world around (“flashbulb memories”)
  • semantic memory of facts and general declarative knowledge

Examples of measuring explicit memory: recollection of facts/events consciously retrieved in response to direct questions

  • (recall VS. recognition tests)
  • One example: Name the Seven Dwarfs from Snow White (recall: 69% accuracy) Vs. selection of names from list
  • (recognition: 86% accuracy)
Encoding of Explicit LTM’s
  • Elaborative rehearsal needed to create meaningful “chunks” and “hierarchies”
  • Must go beyond rote rehearsal/maintenance rehearsal to “deeper” processing (meaning and self-relevance)
  • Not engaging in elaborative rehearsal is the mistake of many students in one type of studying where the student over-engages in rote review of notes and highlighting in books
  • In elaborative rehearsal, you create a rich “semantic network” (see below) built on cues you have created yourself

Serial Position Curve (including the Primacy Effect & Recency Effect)

Craik and Tulving (1975) Experiment

list of words presented, one at a time, followed by one of 3 mental tasks

  • visual judgment 10%
  • acoustic judgment 50%
  • semantic judgment 80%

Conclusion: the more thought(meaningful, conscious associations) required to “process” the words, the easier they were to recognize later.

Semantic Network

In semantic networks, the activation of one concept (mental grouping of items that share common properties) leads to priming of semantically related concepts, making their subsequent retrieval more probable

How did Loftus’ research show the “Reconstructive” Nature of Explicit LTM’s?

research by Elizabeth Loftus (next slide graphic) and others shows the effects of language and external priming on the reconstructive nature of memory.

Implicit or Non-declarative LTM’s

Implicit Memories are not directly accessible to consciousness (they are non-declarative, unconscious). Includes:

  • procedural memory (motor skills, habits, tacit rules)
  • classical conditioning effects (emotional learning)

Examples of measuring implicit memory: nonconscious retention measured by indirect effects on performance

One example: Claparede’s clinical study--hidden pin--with Korsakoff’s patient, (1911) (compare Jimmy, Mr. Thompson, and the below case of “Clive”)

Patients with temporal lobe amnesia involving hippocampal damage, or loss of connections from hippocampus to adjacent structures, still show essentially normal implicit memory function. E.G.:

  • If CC’d to show eyeblink responses to a CS, they show the CR just as strongly in subsequent tests as do non-amnesic subjects
  • If given practice with new motor skill (e.g.., tracing a pattern in a mirror), they show normal improvement from session to session
  • They show emotional conditioning effects similar to normal subjects

item.description:
Element-Wise Operation

add a dot before operator to make them element-wize

item.title: Math240-07 Quantification
item.description:
Terminology

When a quantifier is used on the variable x , we say that this occurrence of the variable is bound. An occurrence of a variable that is not bound by a quantifier or set equal to a particular value is said to be free.

$\exists x (x+y=1)$

x is bound to this quatifier
y is free

$\forall z (z-y=4)$
z bound by $\forall$

$\exists x(P(x) \land Q(x)) \lor \forall x R(x)$
the former x have bound by $\exists$
the latter x have bound by $\forall$

Ex. $\exists x (x>4 \land x<-10) \lor \forall x (x^2\ge 0)$
$\equiv \exists x (x>4 \land x<-10) \lor \forall y (y^2\ge 0$

The scope of a quantifier is the portion of statement to which that quantifier applies

Two statements involving quantifiers and predicates are logically equivalent if they have the same truth value no matter what predicates you plug in and no matter what domain.

Statements involving predicates and quantifiers are logically equivalent if and only if they have the same truth value no matter which predicates are substituted into these statements and which domain of discourse is used for the variables in these propositional functions. We use the notation S ≡ T to indicate that two statements S and T involving predicates and quantifiers are logically equivalent.

Ex. $\forall x (P(x) \land Q(x)) \equiv \forall x P(x) \land \forall x Q(x)$

Two propositions $\scr P$ and $\scr R$ are equivalent
means that $\scr P$ is true if and only if $\scr R$ is true

So to show that $\scr P$ and $\scr R$ are equivalent

  • $\scr R$ true implies $\scr P$ true
  • $\scr P$ true implies $\scr R$ true

Negating

$\lnot(\forall x P(x)) \equiv \exists x \lnot P(x)$

Ex. $\lnot(\forall x (x^2 > x))$
$x=\frac{1}{2}$ false

$\lnot(\exists x Q(x)) \equiv \forall x \lnot Q(x)$

Ex. $\lnot(\exists x (x^2 = -1)$
$\equiv \forall x (x^2 \ne 1)$

These two equivelances are called “De Morgan’s Law for quantifiers”

Ex. $\lnot(\forall x P(x) \rightarrow Q(x))$
$\equiv \exists x \lnot(P(x) \rightarrow Q(x))$
$\equiv \exists x (P(x) \land \lnot Q(x))$

  1. All lions are fierce
  2. Some lions don’t drink coffee
  3. Some fierce creatures don’t drink coffee

P(x) x is a lion
Q(x) x is fierce
R(x) x don’t drink coffee
Domain is all creatures

  1. $\forall x (P(x) \rightarrow Q(x)$
  2. $\exists x (P(x) \land \lnot Q(x))$

item.title: Math240-06 Quantification
item.description:
Quantify the variable

  1. What are the possibilities for x？
  2. How to specify particular possibilities

Universal Quantification

The universal quantification of P(x) is the statement “P(x) for all values of x in the domain.” The notation ∀xP (x) denotes the universal quantification of P(x). Here ∀ is called theuniversal quantifier. We read ∀xP (x) as “for all xP (x)” or “for every xP (x).” An elementfor which P(x) is false is called a counterexample of ∀xP (x).

P(x) could be $x > 3$, $x^2+1>x$

E.g. Q(x) $x^2>x$ domain is all real number. $∀xQ(x)$ is false. $x=1⁄2$ is a counterexample to ∀xQ(x)

E.g. Q(x) $x^2>x$ domain is (1, +$\infty$). ∀xQ(x) is false

Suppose domain is empty, the statement is true.

Existantial Quatification

The existential quantification of P(x) is the proposition “There exists an element x in the domain such that P(x).” We use the notation ∃x P(x) for the existential quantification of P(x). Here ∃ is called the existential quantifier.

Ex. $\exists x (x>3)$ true
Ex. $\exists x (x^2<0)$ false
Ex. $\exists x (x^2\le0)$ true

Ex. $\mathscr R(x): \exists x (x^2>10)$ where the domain is the set of integers greater than or equal to 1 and less than or equal to 4, i.e. domain={1,2,3,4}
$\mathscr R(x) \equiv P(1) ∨ P(2) ∨ P(3) ∨ P(4)$

Ex. There are exactly two x in domain s.t. P(x)
Ex. There are infinitly many x in domain s.t. P(x)
Ex. There is exactly one x s.t. P(x)
i.e. There is a unique x s.t. P(x) :: ∃!x P(x)

Ex. $\exists!x (x^2=0)$ true
Ex. $\exists!y (y^2=1)$ false

Ex. $\forall x<0 (x^2>0) \equiv \forall x (x<0 \rightarrow x^2>0)$

item.title: Math240-04 Propositional Equivalences
item.description:
System Specification

Consistency of a collection of specifications.

X >= 1 and X <= 5
X >= 1 and X <= 0

System specifications should be consistent, that is, they should not contain conflicting requirements that could be used to derive a contradiction. When specifications are not consistent, there would be no way to develop a system that satisfies all specifications.

Ex.
p ∨ ¬q : “The diagnostic message is stored in the buffer or it is retransmitted.”
¬q : “The diagnostic message is not stored in the buffer.”
p → q : “If the diagnostic :-: |message is stored in the buffer, then it is retransmitted.”

p q p ∨ q ¬q p → q
F T T T T

Equivalences

Two compound propositions are equivalent if they have the same truth value no matter what.

p → q and ¬q → ¬p are equivalent

A compound proposition that is always true, no matter what the truth values of the proposi- tional variables that occur in it, is called a tautology.

p ∨ ¬p

A compound proposition that is always false is called a contradiction.

p ∧ ¬p

A compound proposition that is neither a tautology nor a contradiction is called a contingency.

Another definition of equivalent:

The compound propositions p and q are called logically equivalent if p ↔ q is a tautology. The notation p ≡ q denotes that p and q are logically equivalent.

Biconditional Statement

Let p and q be propositions. The biconditional statement p ↔ q is the proposition “p if and only if q .” The biconditional statement p ↔ q is true when p and q have the same truth values, and is false otherwise. Biconditional statements are also called bi-implications.

p q (p → q) ∧ (q → p) p → q q → p

order of operations

  1. ¬
  2. ∧
